metadata.title: A new Nonlocal FEM via Hermitian cubic shape functions for thermal vibration of nano beams surrounded by an elastic matrix

sections.text:
In this study, vibration formulation is presented for nano-scaled beam embedded in an
elastic matrix under the effect of thermal environments. The effect of length scale is investigated using Eringen’s nonlocal elasticity theory. The governing equations are obtained by using Hamilton’s principle and variational approach. Finite element formulation has been achieved based on the nonlocal Euler–Bernoulli beam theory for nano-scaled beam. Galerkin method of weighted residuals is considered for development the global stiffness and mass matrices via Hermitian cubic shape functions. The residue is minimized over the elements, after that the shape function is applied to the obtained equation. The influences of the Pasternak foundation parameter, small scale parameter, mechanical properties of material and thermal effect on vibrational frequency are investigated. As a special case, some results have also been given for silicon carbide nanowires.
Keywords Nonlocal elasticity, Thermal effect, Nano beam, Euler Bernoulli beam theory, Finite Element Formulation.
1 Corresponding author: Tel: +90-242-3106319; Fax: +90-242-3106306 E-mail address: civalek@yahoo.com

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Due to their outstanding features like Young’s modulus, yield strength, flexibility and
conductivity, nanostructures are widely applied to nanoelectronic, nanodevices, nanosensors and nanocomposites. Therefore greatest attention is required in experimental and theoretical researches of micro/nano structures. However, micro/nano structures can be modeled as a beam, shell or plate with classical continuum but the results will not be accurate enough due to their small size (micro/nano). Classical continuum theory is not affected by the distance between atoms; it becomes important when the model size decreases. Therefore classical continuum mechanics have been developed to take into account the size effect by many researchers. These developments have been called the non-classical (higher-order) elasticity theories. The most widely used non-classical theory is the nonlocal theory of Eringen [1]. Many investigations have been made on the mechanical properties of nanomaterials such as static bending [2-15], vibration [16-29], buckling [30-35].
Vibration theory is one of the main subjects of designing in terms of engineering.
Although it is often necessary that many problems about the temperature change are ignored. Nano mechanical devices may have to work in different temperatures. Rocket systems, nanoelectromechanical systems (NEMS) of satellites, high-tech computers, phones processor etc. are some devices which are subjected to very high and very low temperatures. Some articles in the literature have shown that even a small temperature change leads to big changes in the vibration properties of clamped beam [36-42]. In addition, thermal vibration can be used for calculating the Young's modulus of nanostructures.
On the basis of the above evidences the vibration with the effect of temperature has
attracted the attention of many researchers on small scale materials [43-46]. Among them, the
work of Benzair et al. [47] concerned with the Eringen’s non-local elasticity theory for the natural frequency of nonlocal Timoshenko beam with the effect of temperature. Hsu et al. [48] have worked on the resonant frequency to analyze of the chiral single-walled carbon nanotubes subjected to temperature. In their paper, Timoshenko beam model which includes the effect of rotary inertia and shear deformation is used.
There are several methods for modeling the elastic medium. Elastic medium in
Winkler’s idealization is represented by a linear elastic spring system which consists closely spaced independent linear springs. According to this idealization, the deformation will happen only in the region the load is applied. On the other hand, Pasternak model is another elastic medium model. In this model, existence of shear interaction among the spring elements is assumed by connecting the ends of the springs to a beam or plate that only undergoes transverse shear deformation. Some of the other types of modeling elastic medium are Borodicha Filonenko model, Heteny model, and Kerr model. In the literature, studies investigating the vibration behavior of beams which are surrounded by an elastic medium are available. Yang et al. [49] worked the free vibration of an axially moving elastic beam on simple supports embedded in elastic medium. The most existing studies in the literature examine the vibrational behavior of nanostructures surrounded by an elastic medium and include thermal effect.
The influences of elastic foundation and the importance of thermal effect on the
natural frequencies of single-walled carbon nanotubes resting on Winkler foundation are studied by Murmu and Pradhan [50]. Differential quadrature method is being utilized for thermal-vibration response. In order to appraise the effects of shear deformation and rotatory inertia on the natural frequencies of single-walled carbon nanotubes, the transverse vibrations
of Timoshenko beams on Pasternak foundation were investigated by Amirian et al. [51]. Chang [52] has analyzed the thermal vibration and buckling instability of single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNT) conveying fluid and resting on elastic beam based on thermal elasticity mechanics. Chang [52] has replaced the elastic media by a constant Winkler type foundation and used Euler-Bernoulli beam model. The finite element method is adopted to obtain the numerical solutions of the model.
One of the most important materials in nanomaterial is carbon nanotubes. But, carbon
nanotubes have a limited using area due to their performance under very-high temperature. Classical carbon nanotubes can stay stable until 600 0C [53]. Because of this limitation, carbon nanotubes are not suitable to be used in particular areas like high-tech processor, takeoff mechanism of spacecraft etc. In order to use nanotubes in these particular areas which are subjected to very-high and very-low temperatures, scientists have developed carbon nanotubes by composing Carbon atoms with Silica atoms in the structure of nanotube. The new structure has been called Silicon Carbide nanotube (SiCNT). Silicon carbide nanotubes are capable to resist and stay stable until 1000 0C (in air). Silicon carbide was produced in nanorod form by applying high-temperature to silicon carbide powder.
Silicon carbide (SiC) has been researched since 30-40 years in order to use nanotubes
under high temperatures in semiconductor devices. Silica-Carbon compound have very high chemical resistance, high hardness, superior refractory and ceramic properties. The perfect combination of these superior thermal, mechanical, electronic properties and high physicalchemical stability makes SiC an excellent structure for electronic, optical applications. SiC structures can also be used for strengthening phases in metal-, ceramic-, and polymer-matrix composites [54, 55].
In the past 20 years, SiC has been modeled as one-dimensional nanostructures, such as
nanorods, nanowires which contained new features. Theoretical and experimental studies have shown that elasticity modulus and strength of SiC which is in the form of a onedimensional structure is greater than that of the bulk form [55].
In the present article, we have developed thermo-vibrational model for nano simply
supported and clamped beam models on an elastic matrix. Finite element formulation for nonlocal elasticity theory of Euler-Bernoulli beam theory has been used via Hermitian cubic shape functions. The temperature is considered to be constant along the length of a homogeneous beam. The equations are obtained in the dimensionless form and results are presented. Also, some parametric results have been obtained and given for silicon carbide nanowire.

When linear temperature effect increases in a beam which is not fixed from ends and without any axial load, the length of the beam will extend. Therefore, the total strain will be equal the thermal strain. As there is no mechanical strain at the ends of the beam, any stress will not occur. But, in fact, the beams are not free to extend in the axial direction. Therefore uniform temperature rise is held with axially restrains. Thermal expansion will be equal to restraining force but in negative direction

sections.heading: 3.1. Vibration Results for Non-dimensional Form
sections.text:
Depending on the equations obtained above, the thermal vibration of nano materials which is modeled as Euler-Bernoulli beam resting on elastic foundation is discussed in this study. The following dimensionless quantities are used:
EI
TLEA Ptemp 2∆ = α ,
EI
mL 24
4 ω=Ω , EI Lk K ww
4
= , EI
Lk K g
g
2
= (35)
The non-dimensional small scale parameters are taken as e0a/L= 0.0, 0.1, and 0.2,
respectively. Computer code has been developed depending on the finite element method. The number of element was found to be sufficiently accurate results when it is taken equal to 11. We take these values for more precise results as 20.
In the literature, it is difficult to find comparative results for the nonlocal-thermal
vibration of beam which is resting on two-parameter elastic foundation. So first, the effect of thermal coefficient and small scale parameter is neglected. In Table 1, the non-dimensional first five frequencies of simply-supported beams for different Pasternak foundation parameter are compared with those of Togun and Bağdatlı [61], Mustapha and Zhong [62] and Yokoyama [63]. It is obvious from Table 1 that there is a good agreement between the four results. In addition, the study of Togun and Bağdatlı [61] includes the non-linear vibration of the nonlocal Euler-Bernoulli beam resting on Pasternak elastic foundation.
Comparison of first three dimensionless natural frequencies with various nonlocal
parameters for embedded clamped-clamped nanobeam is tabulated in Table 2. As it can be seen from Table 2, results have provided a nice harmony with present results.
The optimum element number for simply supported and clamped boundary conditions
according to various nonlocal parameters is presented in Table 3. As it can be seen, good agreements are obtained for different nonlocal parameters when at least n = 10 for first mode for C-C boundary case while n=7 is enough for simply supported case.
On the other hand in case of obtaining accurate results for higher mode numbers,
element number must be chosen higher than 10 (for mode number three, n=20 is required). Similar to the classical results, the accuracy of the results is increased by the increase of the element number. The nonlocal parameter, elastic foundation parameter and thermal parameter do not significantly affect the accurate element number.
The relationships between non-dimensional natural frequencies, non-dimensional
temperature change for variable values of the non-dimensional small scale parameters are given in Table 4. Table 4 shows the dimensionless fundamental frequencies for simply supported and clamped-clamped boundary conditions. It can be clearly seen from Table 3 that for both boundary conditions of simply supported and clamped-clamped the non-dimensional natural frequencies increase for the negative temperature change while the frequencies decrease for positive temperature change. It is concluded for carbon nanotubes for the case of low or room temperature and high temperature mentioned by Wang et al. [64] and Murmu and Pradhan [50]. In the study of Hsu et al. [48] the frequency decreases with increasing temperature. Hsu et al. [48] have used positive thermal coefficient values in their study. When small scale parameter increases, the frequencies obtained for nonlocal Euler-Bernoulli beam become smaller than those evaluated by classical beam model for all cases. It is also notable that the frequencies of clamped-clamped beams are always greater than the frequencies of simply supported beams.
Table 5, Fig. 2 and Fig. 3 show the effect of elastic foundation parameters and
temperature change on the natural frequency for variable nonlocal parameter. Figs. 3(a) and 4(a) show the increase in positive temperature change. It is obvious that by increasing the positive temperature change, the natural frequencies decrease. Figs. 3(b) and 4(b) describe the
exact opposite of this situation for negative temperature change. However, it is revealed that with an increase in elastic foundation parameters, the natural frequencies also increase for all case. In addition, it can be emphasized from these figures and table that with the increase in shear modulus of shear layer, the non-dimensional frequencies increase significantly.
It can be noted that the axial force occurred by the temperature effect can be positive
or negative. For the positive situation, two cases are possible such as either both the temperature change ( T∆ ) and the thermal expansion coefficient (α) are positive or negative. For the negative situation, two cases are similarly possible like the temperature change is negative and the thermal expansion coefficient is positive or vice versa.

sections.heading: 3.2. Vibration Results for Silicon Carbide Nanowire
sections.text:
The parameters used in calculations for the silicon carbide nanowire are given as
follows: the Young's modulus, E=504.8 GPa, diameter, d=0.89 nm and mass density, ρ=3.10 g/cm3 [65]. Porter et al. [66] mentioned that thermal expansion coefficient should be smaller than 6 µ/K for silicon carbide. So thermal expansion coefficient, α=4 x 10-6 K-1 [67]. The small scale parameters are taken as e0a = 0.0, 1.0 nm, and 2.0 nm, respectively.
In view of these non-dimensional studies, new results for the fundamental frequency
of isolated silicon carbide nanowires without foundation effects are evaluated with simply supported (S-S) and clamped-clamped (C-C) boundary conditions by using nonlocal EulerBernoulli beam theory for variable aspect ratios (L/d) and different nonlocal parameters in Fig. 4. It is found from the figure that the fundamental frequencies tend to decrease when the length-to-diameter ratio increase. Also, it can be interpreted that the frequencies evaluated for simply supported nanowire are smaller than those obtained for fixed-fixed nanowire.
Moreover, it is observed that an increment in the nonlocal parameter leads to a decrement in the natural frequencies.
In Figs. 5 and 6, first three frequencies of simply supported and clamped-clamped
silicon carbide nanowires with a variable aspect ratio for different nonlocal parameters are depicted, respectively. As seen from the figures, frequencies decrease with increasing aspect ratio and nonlocal parameter for two different boundary conditions. It may be noted that the frequencies for clamped-clamped boundary condition are comparatively greater than those for simply supported boundary conditions. As can be expected, when the mode number increases, frequencies increase prominently. Additionally, it can be concluded that the effect of the nonlocal parameter is more evident in the smaller values of L/d.
Figs. 7 and 8 shows the effects of two parameter elastic foundation parameters
respectively on the lowest three frequencies of Euler-Bernoulli silicon carbide nanowire subjected to different edge supports for variable aspect ratios (L/d=10 and L/d=50 respectively) and nonlocal parameters (e0a=0 and e0a=2 nm respectively). It is obvious that by increasing the spring constant parameter and shear modulus of shear layer respectively, the frequencies also increase. However, it is clearly seen from the figures that an increase in aspect ratio and nonlocal parameter gives rise to a decrease in the values of frequencies.
In Fig. 9 and Fig. 10, the change of the lowest three frequencies of simply supported
and clamped-clamped silicon carbide nanowire with the change of temperature for variable nonlocal parameter with L/d=20 are plotted, respectively. It can be seen from these figures that the frequency of silicon carbide nanowire decreases with increment of the temperature. At the same time the frequency decreases with the increase of the nonlocal parameter and this becomes more pronounced in the higher modes.
In order to look the size-dependency, thermal and elastic foundation effects from a
general perspective, Fig. 11 is plotted. As it can be seen in this figure three different graphs for three different temperatures (T=400K, 200K, 0) in yellow, red and blue colors are plotted respectively. In Fig 11, it is clearly seen that the frequency ratio (ωnonlocal / ωlocal) is always less than one in the simply supported boundary condition. But in the clamped-clamped boundary condition, the ratio starts to become more than one for the greater values of the spring constant and shear modulus (Kw = 100 and Kg = 20).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: On the basis of the nonlocal Euler-Bernoulli beam theory, the general equation for thermomechanical vibrations of embedded nano beams and silicon carbide nanowires surrounded by a two-parameter elastic foundation is formulated. The governing equations in motion are derived by implementing Hamilton’s principle in conjunction with Eringen’s nonlocal theory. Finite element method with Hermitian cubic shape functions is employed to solve the resulting dynamic equation. In order to demonstrate the accuracy and validity of the present analysis, some comparative results are presented with the previous works available in the literature. It is observed that the difference between the frequencies of classical beam model and those of the nonlocal beam model increases as the mode number and nonlocal parameter increase. Also, it can be interpreted that the frequencies decrease by considering the thermal effect while the frequencies increase with inclusion of the elastic foundation effects.

metadata.abstractText: In this study, vibration formulation is presented for nano-scaled beam embedded in an elastic matrix under the effect of thermal environments. The effect of length scale is investigated using Eringen’s nonlocal elasticity theory. The governing equations are obtained by using Hamilton’s principle and variational approach. Finite element formulation has been achieved based on the nonlocal Euler–Bernoulli beam theory for nano-scaled beam. Galerkin method of weighted residuals is considered for development the global stiffness and mass matrices via Hermitian cubic shape functions. The residue is minimized over the elements, after that the shape function is applied to the obtained equation. The influences of the Pasternak foundation parameter, small scale parameter, mechanical properties of material and thermal effect on vibrational frequency are investigated. As a special case, some results have also been given for silicon carbide nanowires.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
